label: What is the risk management culture in your company?

answers.label: We do not really have one.

recommendations.label: It is always advised to establish and maintain an appropriate governance and risk management framework, to identify and address risks for the all networks and services.

answers.label: There are risk management governance responsibilities in place.
Our company performs a Risk Analysis at least once every year.
Our company has a documented strategy combining both reacting to incidents and the prevention of incidents.
Our company has third-party risk management in place.
Our company is covering critical risks even outside of service contracts with providers/third-parties.

recommendations.label: Having and maintaining an appropriate information security policy and charter. label: Do you have specific regulations in your sector concerning cybersecurity?
Are you obliged to comply with any of the following regulations?

answers.label: No obligation to comply to any regulation.

recommendations.label:
If you are a simple SME, you can consider the guidance from ENISA:
  • Cybersecurity guide for SMEs
  • Report cybersecurity for SMEs

If you are a simple SME, you can consider the guidance from ENISA:
  • Cybersecurity guide for SMEs
  • Report cybersecurity for SMEs

If you are obliged to comply with the NIS directive, then you should consider this mapping table of security measures provided by ENISA. In addition, depending on your sector you should consider this documents:
  • Digital service provider
    • Minimum security measures for digital service providers
  • Telecom sector
    • Guideline on security measures under the EECC
  • Healthcare sector
    • Cloud security for healthcare services
    • Good practices for the security of healthcare services
  • Transport sector (railways)
    • Railway cybersecurity
  • Energy sector
    • Communication network interdependencies in smart grids
    • Power sector dependency
  • Financial sector
    • EU Cybersecurity Initiatives in the Finance Sector
    • Mobile payments security
    • Blockchain security
    • Network and information security in the finance sector

If you are a simple SME, you can consider the guidance from ENISA:
  • Cybersecurity guide for SMEs
  • Report cybersecurity for SMEs

label: Is your organization voluntarily compliant with any of the following standards and guidelines?

answers.label: We are not compliant with any standards nor guidelines.

recommendations.label: Irrespective of your obligations in terms of risk management and cybersecurity, you should consider the 29 Security Objectives listed by ENISA split in 8 areas, and ordered by level of sophistication. How often does your organization communicate with the authorities in Luxembourg (e.g., CSSF, ILR, CNPD or others)?
service_category: Collaboration at EU and National Level
section: Collaboration at EU and National Level

answers.label: Less than or exactly once a year

label: When is the last time you collaborated with ISACs, CSIRTs or similar organisations, or with the MISP community in your sector?
service_category: Collaboration at EU and National Level
section: Collaboration at EU and National Level

recommendations.label: It is always advised to stay in contact with the CSIRT and MISP community to stay informed and be up to date on threats and incidents in relation to your services and networks.

answers.label: Please indicate the frequency or if it is another organisation:

label: In case of a security incident, does your organization interact with other service operators to solve the issue, or is it more in competition with them?
service_category: Collaboration at EU and National Level
section: Collaboration at EU and National Level

recommendations.label: It is always a good approach to work with operators in the same sector as it collectively helps to mitigate attacks and provides better protection against complete blackouts. Additionally contracts between operators can be made to sub-rent some of their service platform to the attached operator so the clients do not have too much of a service interruption. One such way of collaboration could be through the MISP community and/or the ILR.

label: What do you consider is the utility to you when your organisation has to report incidents to authorities?

answers.label: It is a burden for us.
Reporting neither helps nor hinders us.

label: To whom to you report the same incident, when it appears?
What kind of feedback would you consider as helpful to receive from an authority following the mandatory incident reporting?

answers.label: Connecting to companies with the same issues.
Guidance on solving the issue based on previous experience.
Guidance on preventing those kinds of issues in the future.

label: Do you consider you have a skill shortage in terms of cybersecurity and risk management?

answers.label: Yes indeed, we don't have enough skills in these areas.

recommendations.label: During the employment for an employee or the contract of external collaborators, Interns and other employment, it is advised to ensure that personnel have sufficient security knowledge and that they are provided with regular security and awareness trainings. Additionally, it is important to have and correctly maintain an appropriate process for managing changes in personnel or changes in their roles and responsibilities, while verifying access to internal information an personnel accounts.

answers.label: No, we have the skills but the problems are elsewhere.

recommendations.label: Operational procedures for correctly operating and to ensure correct operation of your services, information systems and networks. Additionally, it is essential to have and maintain contingency plans and strategy for ensuring continuity of your services provided, information systems and networks.

label: Which of the measures below would be of help to your organisation?

answers.label: To be put in contact with other operators in Luxembourg and abroad, related to risk management and information security.
To receive more guidance on both operational and technical areas, local or EU level.
To have a central platform to help security experts from different operators, communicate and discuss issues.
To have more transparency from the authorities in Luxembourg (what they want to see, what approach they will take to do any audits, etc).
A single reporting platform to report incidents to multiple authorities.
